comments:
Run any program with a break point and when the program reach the breakpoint,
eclipse pop up and error window.  The debug call stack get stuck in "pending".

Here is the error message from .metedata/.log

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 4 2 2005-04-05 17:27:43.751
!MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Debug".
!STACK 0
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.sun.jdi.Method.isVarargs()Z
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIStackFrame.getArgumentTypeNames(JDIStackFrame.java:333)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.JDIModelPresentation.getStackFrameText(JDIModelPresentation.java:1673)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.JDIModelPresentation.getText(JDIModelPresentation.java:213)
	at
org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.LazyModelPresentation.getText(LazyModelPresentation.java:153)
	at
org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DelegatingModelPresentation.getText(DelegatingModelPresentation.java:156)
	at
org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.views.DebugViewLabelDecorator$LabelJob.run(DebugViewLabelDecorator.java:323)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:67)

What VM are you using? Did M5 work for you?
I've never seen this happen on windows.

I am using jre1.5.0_02.

I am using this argument to start eclipse:

vmargs -Xbootclasspath/a:"<path-to-jdk>\lib\tools.jar"

When I remove it.  Debug works.
I want to add that 3.1M5a works even if I start eclipse with the argument above.

By adding tools.jar to the boot classpath, the Eclipse classloader will load 
the Sun implementation of JDI, rather than the Eclipse implementation. Why do 
you need tools.jar on the bootpath?

I was trying out Pollinate and the installation specifies that I have to launch
eclipse and specify "-vmargs -Xbootclasspath/a:C:\jdk1.5.0\lib\tools.jar"

For your reference, here is the url to the installation instructino for Pollinate:
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextech.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/pollinate-home/downloads.html

Fixed.
Changed files: BinaryBasedSourceGenerator, MethodImpl, Method, JDIStackFrame
Quickly went through Interfaces defined in com.sun.jdi. Looks like we match up now (again?).
